hero.subtitle: The Research
hero.title: About the Study
hero.description: This study focuses on analyzing heart rate patterns during running using Unsupervised Machine Learning techniques to detect potential anomalies that may indicate cardiovascular risks.

objectives.title: Project Objectives
list: To develop an effective unsupervised machine learning model for detecting heart rate anomalies during running.
To apply the developed model to real-time data from wearable devices to provide early warnings.
To reduce the risk of unforeseen heart failure events during exercise.

volunteerInfoPage.title: Information for Volunteers
volunteerInfoPage.subtitle: Everything you need to know about participating in the study.

faq.a: We are looking for individuals aged 18-60 who run at least 3 times per week and have been doing so for at least one month. Participants must use a smart device (like a Garmin, Apple Watch, etc.) to record their running data.

faq.q: What is the process for participating?
faq.a: The researcher will explain the project objectives and ask for your permission to access your running data. You will then be guided on how to export and send your data (e.g., heart rate, speed, distance) from your fitness app. The process takes about 10-20 minutes and is a one-time data collection.

There are no physical risks as the research only uses existing data from your device. You might feel some inconvenience giving access to your data or spend 10-20 minutes of your time. If you feel uncomfortable at any point, you can ask the researcher for help or withdraw.

faq.q: How is my privacy and data protected?
faq.a: Your privacy is our top priority. The data used will not include your name, email, or other personal identifiers. All data will be presented in an aggregated, summary form and will be stored securely. All digital files will be destroyed after the research is complete.

faq.q: What are the benefits of participating?
faq.a: While there are no direct benefits to you, your participation is a valuable contribution to sports science. The results will help develop technology for real-time health monitoring, potentially reducing the risk of sudden cardiac events for runners in the future.
